De veritate; Meditatio redemptionis humanae; Epistolae 101, 112, 416, 121, 168, 258, 231, 37, 65, 160, 161, 188, 281, 285; Vita S. Anselmi; Declaratio cuiusdam de Anselm de conceptu virginali et originali peccato  aGaunilo: Pro insipiente. (Pseudo-) Anselmus: Expositio membrorum et actuum Dei; De voluntate Dei. (Pseudo-) Anselmus [Eadmerus Cantuariensis]: De sancti Anselmi similitudinibus, cap. 1-185. (Pseudo-) Anselmus: De mensuratione crucis. (Pseudo-) Aurelius Augustinus: Meditationes ('Domine Deus meus da cordi meo' I, cap. 1-9). (Pseudo-) Anselmus: Dialogus Anselmi et Beatae Mariae Virginis de passione Jesu Christi. (Pseudo-) Anselmus [Ecbertus Schonaugiensis]: Stimulus amoris. (Pseudo-) Anselmus [Radulphus Cantuariensis]: Homilia in Lucam (10, 38) 'Intravit Jesus in quoddam castellum'. Eadmerus: De excellentia virginis Mariae. Honorius Augustodunensis: De imagine mundi [lib. I-II]. Anselmus: Orationes ad sanctam Mariam; Forma et mores beatae Mariae [extract]. Ed: Johannes Andreas, bishop of Aleria  aRomebIn domo Petri de Maximis [Conradus Sweynheym and Arnoldus Pannartz]c28 Feb. 1469  cf°  aContents: Asinus aureus, sive Metamorphosis. Florida. Apologia. De deo Socratis. De Platonis dogmate. Add: [Pseudo- Aristoteles]: De mundo (Tr: Apuleius). Hermes Trismegistus: Asclepius (Tr: Apuleius). Alcinous: Epitome disciplinarum Platonis (Tr: Petrus Balbus). On the probably erroneous attribution of Alcinous, Epitome to Albinus (cf. GW), see Alcinoos, Enseignement des doctrines de Platon, ed. John Whittaker (Paris, 1990). De mundo is the Latin reworking by Apuleius of the Pseudo- Aristotelian tract. The translation of Asclepius is probably not by Apuleius CIBN)4 aGoffcA9344 aHCc1314*4 aPellc9234 aCIBNcA-4924 aAquilonc374 aLefèvrec284 aDelislec1154 aIGIc7694 aIDLc3844 aIBEc5014 aCCIR A-1014 aColl(S)c864 aLőkkös(Cat BPU)c384 aVoull(B)c33034 aSchmittcI 33034 aWalshc1283, 12844 aOatesc13584 aBod-inccA-3694 aSheppardc26074 aPrc32974 aBMCcIV 64 aBSB-InkcA-6584 aGWc2301  aBritish Libraryj167.f.17 = IB.17116jG.8997 = IB.17115  aCambridge UL01813nam a22004817  ia00936000800715s1493                        lat  1 aApuleius Madaurensis, Lucius10aOpera. Ed: Johannes Andreas, bishop of Aleria  aVenicebPhilippus Pinciusc30 Apr. 1493  cf°  aContents: Asinus aureus, sive Metamorphosis. Florida. Apologia. De deo Socratis. De Platonis dogmate. Add: [Pseudo- Aristoteles]: De mundo (Tr: Apuleius). Hermes Trismegistus: Asclepius (Tr: Apuleius). Alcinous: Epitome disciplinarum Platonis (Tr: Petrus Balbus). On the probably erroneous attribution of Alcinous, Epitome to Albinus (cf. GW), see Alcinoos, Enseignement des doctrines de Platon, ed. John Whittaker (Paris, 1990). De mundo is the Latin reworking by Apuleius of the Pseudo- Aristotelian tract. Comm: Johannes de Lapide  aBaselbJohann Amerbachc[not after 1495]  cf°  aWith general title: Explanatio librorum artis logicae Porphyrii et Aristotelis. Contents: Porphyrius: Isagoge in Aristotelis praedicamenta (Tr: Boethius). Gilbertus Porretanus: Liber sex principiorum. Apparently the versions were mixed in the printing house. De moribus ecclesiae catholicae. De quantitate animae. De libero arbitrio. De magistro. De opere monachorum. De dono perseverantiae. De decem chordis. De vita et moribus clericorum. Regula tertia. Pseudo-Augustinus: De grammatica. Principia rhetorices. Principia dialecticae. Eusebius Corradus: De vita et moribus sancti Augustini. Augustinus Ticinensis: Vita sancti Guarini. Add: Speculum animae peccatricis  aParisb[Pasquier or Jean Bonhomme]c16 Sept. 1479  c4°  aIn some copies, the date in the colophon is printed as 'lxxÖ dec&îbreve;o nono' (cf. BMC, GW), in others, correctly, as 'lxxÖ nono' (cf. C 765, Pell and Oates)  aDe conflictu vitiorum is apparently the work of Ambrosius Autpertus. The Speculum animae peccatricis, sometimes falsely attributed to Dionysius Carthusiensis, is now attributed either to Jacobus de Gruytrode (cf. Bloomfield) or to Jacobus de Clusa (cf. L. Meier, Die Werke des Erfurter Karthäusers Jakob von Jüterbog, Münster, 1955) (CIBN). Jacobus de Clusa also recorded as Jacobus de Jüterbog or de Paradiso (Verfasserlexikon 2, Bd 4 col.478ff)4 aGoffcA12554 aHCc8402 (Speculum)4 aCc764 = 7654 aPellc15754 aCIBNcA-7274 aHillardc2284 aBufféventc584 aPéligryc1094 aOatesc29054 aBod-inccA-5694 aSheppardc61024 aPrc79174 aBMCcVIII 124 aGWc2942  aBritish LibraryjIA.39275  aCambridge UL, Trinity College01304nam a22004457  ia01257000801022 1473                        lat  0 aAugustinus, Aurelius10aDe consensu evangelistarum  aLauingenb[Printer of Augustinus 'De consensu evangelistarum']c12 Apr. 1473  cf°  aThe former Maihingen copy included two proofsheets, cf. Davis 688 is another copy of part III only, in a contemporary Bavarian binding in the Henry Davis Gift (M.M. Foot, The Henry Davis Gift: a collection of bookbindings, vol.2, London, 1983 no.322). Csapodi, Gb Jb 1965, pp.122-234 aGoffcB154 aCc800 = 8014 aPellc16914 aHillardc2564 aArnoultc1844 aPéligryc1284 aZehnackerc3394 aIDLc6074 aVoull(Trier)c22674 aHubay(Augsburg)c2534 aOatesc28844 aPrc78714 aBMCcVIII 274 aGWc3175  aBritish LibraryjIA.40704  aCambridge UL02451nam a22005777  ib00020000801022 14601472                    lat  0 aBalbus, Johannes10aCatholicon  a[MainzbPrinter of the 'Catholicon']c'1460' [not before 1469]  cf°  aThree issues can be distinguished in spite of identical typesetting: a) printed on vellum or Bull's Head paper; b) on Galliziani paper; c) on Tower & Crown paper. This has given rise to the theory that issue a) was printed in 1460, issue b) in 1469 and issue c) about 1472; see P. Needham, in BSA 76 (1982) pp.395-456 and the articles "zur Catholicon-Forschung" in Wolfenbütteler Notizen zur Buchgeschichte 13 (1988) pp.105-232. For an alternative theory that all three states were printed about 1469, see L. Add: De conscientia aedificanda; Epistola de gubernatione rei familiaris; Orationes devotissimae; De ordine vitae et morum institutione; Speculum de honestate vitae; Octo puncta perfectionis assequendae  a[ParisbPierre Levetcabout 1495]  c8°  aPseudo- Bernardus. The true author of De gubernatione rei familiaris is Bernardus Silvestris (Lexikon für Theologie und Kirche. 2 Aufl. (Freiburg 1957-67) Bd.2 col.248). The Meditationes are also attributed to Hugo de Sancto Victore, De conscientia to an anonymous Cistercian of the 12th century, De ordine vitae to Johannes Homo Dei (cf Hillard)4 aCc9744 aPellc21244 aGirardc854 aHillardc344a4 aParguezc1654 aPolain(B)c40864 aIBEc9534 aIBPortc2794 aMendesc1894 aMadsenc6294 aLeuze(Isny)c1554 aSack(Freiburg)c5714 aOatesc29884 aGWc4037  aCambridge UL00813nam a22002417  4500001001100000008004100011100002900052245004700081260005000128300000800178500015500186510001500341510001300356510001300369510001400382510001600396510002200412510001300434510001600447510003200463852004200495951003400537ib00411000801022m14981499                    eng  1 aBernardus Claravallensis10aMeditationes de interiori homine [English]  aWestminsterbWynkyn de Wordec[about 1498-99]  c4°  aThe book has the imprint 9 March 1496, taken over from the preceding edition, Duff 41. Needham (Christie's, Doheny 16, Sotheby's Schøyen 6), who prefers to see Mentelin in association with Rusch as responsible for the work of the R-printer. With the Glossa Ordinaria of pseudo-Walafrid Strabo and interlinear glosses of Anselmus Laudunensis  a[StrassburgbAdolf Rusch, for Anton Koberger at Nurembergcnot after 1480]  cf°  a4 parts  aAscribed to Amerbach by A. Hartmann (Amerbach-korrespondenz (1942), I, 2 n.2). The printing, however, seems to have been done by Rusch at Strassburg with types borrowed from Amerbach: F. Geldner in Archiv für Geschichte des Buchwesens, 23 (1982), cols 684-88. GW dates shortly after 23 Sept. 1481 but manuscript notes in the Sion College copy and in Oates 124 are dated 1480. The quire signatures, in multiple sequences of the first seven letters of the alphabet, are perhaps early press figures (BMC). For variants see CIBN  aOn the authorship of the Glossa Ordinaria see B. Ed: Julien Macho  a[LyonsbMartin Husscnot after 1477]  cf°  aWoodcuts. Distinguished from the second Huss edition by 'nouuel' twice in the title instead of 'nouel' (B. T. Chambers, Bibliography of French Bibles, Geneva, 1983, 4)  aThe Bible moralisée in the last version it assumed in the manuscript tradition (CIBN). Add: Speculum animae peccatricis; Ars moriendi "Cum de praesentis exilii miseria mortis transitus"; Hugo de Sancto Caro: Speculum ecclesiae et sacerdotum; Rodericus Zamorensis: Speculum vitae humanae; Dionysius Carthusiensis: Speculum conversionis peccatorum  aLouvainbJohannes de Westfaliac[about 1481-83]  cf°  a6 parts  aDated from paper evidence (WILC). HPT dated [1477-83]  aReproductions of the watermarks found in the paper used in this edition are provided by the Koninklijke Bibliotheek, National Library of the Netherlands.  aThe Speculum de confessione is probably by Berengarius Fredoli. The Speculum animae peccatricis, sometimes falsely attributed to Dionysius Carthusiensis, is now attributed either to Jacobus de Gruytrode (cf. Bloomfield) or to Jacobus de Clusa (cf. L. Meier, Die Werke des Erfurter Karthäusers Jakob von Jüterbog, Münster, 1955) (CIBN). Jacobus de Clusa also recorded as Jacobus de Jüterbog or de Paradiso (Verfasserlexikon 2, Bd 4 col.478ff). Ars moriendi sometimes attributed to Matthaeus de Cracovia or to Albertus Magnus (and in Italian editions to Dominicus Capranica, Cardinal of Fermo); cf. A. Madre, Nikolaus von Dinkelsbühl (Beiträge zur Geschichte der Philos. u. Theol. des Mittelalters 40 (1965) p.292-295), and D. Mertens, Iacobus Carthusiensis (Göttingen, 1976) p.1814 aGoffcB13464 aCc13974 aCampc3924 aILCc4964 aPellc31264 aElliott-Loosec1554 aCIBNcB-9504 aAquilonc186 + 405 + 47 + 3894 aHillardc5334 aZehnackerc5984 aPolain(B)c9474 aIGIc7354 aIDLc10934 aIBEc4844 aColl(S)c814 aPad-Inkc3794 aWalshc39204 aOatesc37354 aBod-inccB-6214 aSheppardc71014 aPrc92564 aBMCcIX 150 (Dionysius Carthusiensis only)4 aGWc5829  aBritish LibraryjIB.49225jIB.49226(2)qIB.49225 an acquisition 1963, not in BMC. Ed: Michael Fernus  aRomebEucharius Silber, for Michael Fernusc31 Oct. 1495  cf°  aWoodcuts  aContents: In seven parts. Ed: Michael Fernus. I) Petrus Sabinus: Decastichon. Fernus: Tetrastichon; Disticha; Vita Campani; Ad Campani gloriam carmen; Epitaphium Campani. Add: Fernus: Epistolae (with index). Jacobus Antiquarius: Epistola ad Fernum. II) Fernus: De codicibus postillatis devitandis; Marginales in opuscula Campani notulae; Praefatio. Campanus: De ingratitudine fugienda; De regendo magistratu; De dignitate matrimonii; Descriptio Thrasimeni; De fratris obitu ad cardinalem Papiensem; In varios auctores censurae; Coram Pio II abcessuri ad Venetos adolescentis Columnensis oratio; Oratio ad senatum Venetum; Oratio in ascensione domini  aIII) Fernus: Marginalia in orationes annotamenta; Praefatio. Campanus: Oratio in initio studii a. 1455 Perusiae habita; Oratio cinericia; De spiritu sancto oratio; De circumcisione oratio; In festo S. Stephani oratio; In festo S. Thomae de Aquino oratio; Oratio ad principes Germanorum contra Turcos in conventu Ratisponensi anno 1471 habita; In exsequiis Pii papae II oratio; In funere Nelli de Balionibus oratio; In funere parentis D. Johannis archiepiscopi Beneventani oratio; In funere Cardinalis Saxoferratensis oratio; Oratio in exsequiis Baptistae Sfortiae, Urbini comitissae. IV) Epistolarum libri ix. V) Vita Pii Papae II. VI) Historiae Bracchii (Andreae Fortebrachii) libri vi. VII) Elegiae et epigrammata; Carmina tria nuperrime inventa. Differs from GW 8031 transcription in [a2]: 'incipit', b1: 'uengon', b4v: 'Gregorius ... caro ... qualiacunque ... pacini'. The correction of the misprint 'caro' to 'raro' in GW 8031, and further wear to the woodcut blocks there, suggest that this is the earlier of the two editions. Signed a3, b, b2 only. a22003257  id00145700861202 1473                        lat  10aDialogi decem variorum auctorum  a[ColognebPrinter of the 'Flores Sancti Augustini' (Johann Schilling)c1473]  cf°  aThe date The printer is tentatively identified as Johann Veldener by S. Corsten, in Journal of the Printing Historical Society 11 (1976/77) pp. 1-18, but as Schilling by Needham(Corsten Festschrift) pp. 121 ff.  aCon: Isidorus Hispalensis: De spirituali consolatione. Hieronymus: De consolatione infirmorum (i.e. Maximus Taurinensis: Epistula ad amicum aegrotum). Bartholomaeus Fatius: De vitae felicitate. Seneca: De remediis fortuitorum. Laurentius Valla: De libero arbitrio. Maphaeus Vegius: Philalethes; De felicitate ac miseria. Poggius Florentinus: Contra avaritiam. Bonaccursius de Montemagno: Controversia de nobilitate. 1475  cf°  aBMC and GW describe a variant incipit  aContents: Pars 1: Praecepta artis rhetoricae (revised and augmented version, with excerpts taken from classical authors and Italian humanists and formulas for letter-writing). Pars II: An anthology of prose writers (Cicero, Lactantius, Macrobius, Plutarchus [Apophthegmata], G. Burleius, Valerius Maximus etc.). Zehnacker dates about 1471  aThe Memoriale of Alexander incorporates the work of Jordanus Osnaburgensis, De imperio romano. Only part A is dated in each issue. Since some copies of this are mixed, and since it is difficult to determine the make-up of the various editions, each part is here registered separately. BMC queries Voulliéme's distribution of the undated parts between the dated editions, ascribing its copy of Voull(K) 563 (D) to one of the two later editions (cf. Goff H99 and H100) ). Proctor assigned to Grüninger at Strassburg. A misreading of the colophon ('nonagesimose / ptimo') created the ghost edition of 1491 registered as Goff J128 (from Panzer, Pell(V) and Copinger, who assigned to Basel). P. Needham (Sotheby's NY, 17-18 June 1992, 24) dates the edition about 1476; dated not after 1481 by BMC and others. Add: Petrus de Tussignano: Consilium pro peste evitanda. With Rhasis: De aegritudinibus puerorum  aVenicebJohannes and Gregorius de Gregoriis, de Forlivioc28 Mar. 1500  cf°  aJohannes de Ketham can be convincingly identified as Hans von Kircheim of Swabia, fl. 1455-1470, professor of medicine in Vienna, who used this collection for his lectures and recommended it to his pupils. This collection of texts was in circulation by 1400. See K. Sudhoff, The Fasciculus Medicinae of Johannes de Ketham, Alemanus. Assigned by Campbell, Kronenberg and Oates to Deventer  aDe funerali pompa (Dial. mortuorum 10), with Rinucius' preface, is printed here under the title Dialogus quomodo solus nudus per Acheronta transvehi potest, and the translation assigned to 'Arispa' (so catalogued by Goff and others). The De praecedentia ... (Dial. mortuorum 12) really translated by Aurispa is also found under the title De praestantia (De presidentia) trium principum4 aGoffcL3254 aHCc10273*4 aCamp-Kronc11764 aVoull(K)cp.3384 aSajó-Soltészc21034 aIBPc34644 aIDLc30064 aMadsenc25334 aGünt(L)c7974 aVoull(B)c10314 aSchülingc5604 aBormc17204 aPad-Inkc4374 aOatesc35444 aRhodes(Oxford Colleges)c11154 aBod-inccL-1744 aSheppardc10144 aPrc14044 aBSB-InkcL-240  aCambridge UL00694nam a22002537  4500001001100000008004100011100002600052245006100078260004900139300000800188510001400196510001900210510002500229510001600254510001400270510001400284510001900298510001900317510001600336510001300352510001600365852003000381951002900411il00327500820128s1476                        lat  1 aLucianus Samosatensis10aVera historia [Latin]. Tr: Lilius (Tifernas) Castellanus. Add: De asino aureo; Philosophorum vitae; Scipio; Tyrannus; Scaphidium (Dialogus de funerali pompa); Palinurus; Charon; Diogenes; Terpsion; Hercules; Virtus dea; In amorem; Timon; Sermo de calumnia; Laus muscae  aMilanbUldericus Scinzenzelerc22 Mar. 1497  c4°  aThe translations after the Vera Historia are by various hands. The Palinurus attributed to Lucianus is in fact the De felicitate et miseria of Maphaeus Vegius. The Carmina heroica in amorem are a free translation of the second idyll of Moschus (BMC VIII 412). Virtus Dea, purporting to be a translation from Lucianus by Carolus Marsupinus, is an original Latin work of Leo Baptista Alberti4 aGoffcL3304 aHCc102624 aGfTc20544 aPell Msc7296 (7237)4 aCIBNcL-2514 aIDLc30074 aIBEc35844 aIGIc58434 aVoull(B)c31214 aBMCcVI 771  aBritish LibraryjIA.26769  aCambridge UL (bequeathed in 1964, ULC 2309.5, not in Oates)01369nam a22004337  il00333000800611s1486                        lat  1 aLucretius Carus, Titus10aDe rerum natura  aVeronabPaulus Fridenpergerc28 Sept. 1486; 1 Oct. 1486  cf°4 aGoffcL3334 aHCRc102824 aGfTc23534 aKlebsc623.24 aPell Msc7307 (7246 bis)4 aCIBNcL-2564 aAquilonc4474 aLefèvrec2854 aZehnackerc14534 aDelislec11334 aIGIc58664 aIBPc59054 aIJL2c2534 aIDLc30084 aColl(S)c6754 aMadsenc25394 aVoull(B)c45774 aGünt(L)c39004 aMittler-Kindc4294 aWalshc3383, 33844 aOatesc25994 aBod-inccL-1824 aSheppardc57084 aPrc69234 aBMCcVII 9534 aGWcM19142  aBritish LibraryjC.3.c.1 = IB.30765jG.9737 = IB.30766jIB.30763jIB.30764qG.9737 has sheet c4 and quire d in another setting-up. The standard was 24 lines per page (BMC, Polain). Three issues can be distinguished: (A) In 8°, with a colophon naming Bartholomaeus Campanus Ponticuruanus, who was a press-reader. Opening k3v-k4r has 17 and 16 lines to the page (BMC, Hain, Polain(B) 2645). (B) In 4°, with a colophon naming the printers. Opening k3v-k4r as in state A. BMC assumes that a 'v' has dropped out of the printed year-date. The colophon of the second part reads 'xxiii kalendas decembres'. Ed: Sebastian Brant  aBaselbJohann Amerbachc1496  cf°  aIn some copies leaves 57-60 are bound after leaf 192  aIncludes the Ydiota de vera sapientia of Nicolaus de Cusa, wrongly ascribed to Petrarca (E. P. Goldschmidt; Medieval texts and their first appearance in print (London, 1943), p. 133). Contents: bucolicum carmen; De vita solitaria; De remediis utriusque fortunae; Secretum; De vera sapientia; Rerum memorandarum lib.; Invectivae contra medicum obiurgantem; Epistolae familiares; Epistolae sine titulo; Epistola ad Carolum IV; Epistola de studiorum suorum successibus ad posteritatem; Psalmi poenitentiales; De viris illustribus. Sebastian Brant: De commendatione impressionis Francisci Petrarchae. Benvenutus de Rambaldis: Libellus Augustalis. ip00479100910410s1476                        lat  1 aPetrus Lombardus10aSententiarum libri IV  a[StrassburgbPrinter of Henricus Ariminensis (Georg Reyser?)cabout 1476]  cf°  aPrinted in type (1:120G) ascribed to Georg Reyser by Ohly, and tentatively to Heinrich Eggestein by Needham, Christie's, Doheny 19. Dated about 1475-76 in Amelung, Sack and CIBN, not after 1468 in Goff. The Toronto UL copy has a rubricator's date of 1468 but the paper is to be dated about 1475-76 (Piccard for Amelung; also P. Needham in BSA 76 (1982) pp. 406-408); Amelung suggests that the rubricator intended 1478  aDated on paper evidence cf. Add: (pseudo-) Ptolemaeus: Centiloquium; Hermes Trismegistus: Centiloquium; De stellis beibeniis; Bethem: Centiloquium; De horis planetarum; De significatione triplicitatum ortus; Almansor: Propositiones. 1472]  cf°  aThe BL copy has three extra printed leaves with letters of dedication to 1) Robert d'Estouteville, provost of Paris; 2) Jean II de Bourbon, Duc d'Auvergne; and 3) Louis XI. The last, dated 22 Apr. 1472, gives the first names of the printers; the same letter is found in the HEHL copy. Add: Dionysius Carthusiensis: Speculum conversionis peccatorum. Pseudo- Aurelius Augustinus (i.e. Bernardus de Parentinis): De dignitate sacerdotum. Vita Udonis episcopi. Ad sacerdotes. Speculum animae peccatricis. Henricus de Bitterfeld: De horis canonicis dicendis. Ars moriendi "Cum de praesentis exilii miseria mortis transitus..."  aBesançonb[Petrus Metlinger]c1488  c4°  aFor the arrangement of the tracts, which can be found in any order, by quires, see BMC and Sack  aThe Speculum animae peccatricis, sometimes falsely attributed to Dionysius Carthusiensis, is now attributed either to Jacobus de Gruytrode (cf. Bloomfield) or to Jacobus de Clusa (cf. L. Meier, Die Werke des Erfurter Karthäusers Jakob von Jüterbog, Münster, 1955) (CIBN). Jacobus de Clusa also recorded as Jacobus de Jüterbog or de Paradiso (Verfasserlexikon 2, Bd 4 col.478ff). Ars moriendi sometimes attributed to Matthaeus de Cracovia or to Albertus Magnus (and in Italian editions to Dominicus Capranica, Cardinal of Fermo); cf. A. Madre, Nikolaus von Dinkelsbühl (Beiträge zur Geschichte der Philos. u. Theol. des Mittelalters 40 (1965) p.292-295), and D. The Declamatio is spuriously attributed to M. Ianuarias", interpreted in BMC, Polain, IGI and Sajó-Soltész as 22 Dec  aCon: Contra errores Graecorum. De rationibus fidei contra Saracenos, sive De declaratione articulorum contra Graecos, Armenos et Saracenos. Compendium theologiae. De praeceptis caritatis. De articulis fidei et ecclesiae sacramentis. Expositio super Symbolum apostolorum. Expositio orationis Dominicae. Expositio super Ave Maria, sive salutationis angelicae. Articuli CVIII ex Petro de Tarentasia. Articuli XLII ad Johannem Vercellensem. Articuli XXXVI ad lectorem Venetum. Articuli VI ad lectorem Bisuntinum. De differentia verbi. De natura verbi intellectus. De angelis. De unitate intellectus contra Averroem. Contra retrahentes, sive De perfectione christianae religionis. De perfectione vitae spiritualis. Contra impugnantes Dei. De regimine principum. De regimine Judaeorum, sive De Iudeis ad petitionem. De forma absolutionis. Expositio primae Decretalis. Expositio secundae Decretalis. De sortibus ad Jacobum de Burgo. De astrorum iudiciis. De aeternitate mundi. De fato  aDe principio individuationis. De ente et essentia. De principiis rerum naturalium. De natura materiae. De mixtione elementorum. De occultis operibus naturae, sive Libellus occultorum naturae effectuum. De motu cordis. De instantibus. De quattuor oppositis. De demonstratione. De fallaciis. De propositionibus modalibus. De natura accidentis. De natura generis. De potentiis animae. De tempore. De pluralitate formarum. De dimensionibus interminatis. De natura syllogismorum. Summa totius logicae Aristotelis. De sensu respectu. De inventione medii. De natura luminis. De natura loci. De intellectu et intelligibili, sive De modo intelligendi. De eo quo est et quod est. De universalibus. De corpore Christi. De venerabili sacramento sermones XXXII, sive Modus procedendi in sermones de sacramento eucharistiae. De eucharistia ad modum decem praedicamentorum, sive De corpore Christi. De humanitate Christi. De dilectione Dei et proximi. De divinis moribus. De beatitudine  aDe modo confitendi et puritate conscientiae. De officio sacerdotis. Expositio missae, sive De officio missae. De emptione et venditione ad tempus. Epistola de modo studendi, sive Epistola exhortatoria. In Boethium de hebdomadibus. In Boethium de Trinitate. De vitiis et virtutibus, sive Quaternarius. De concordantiis in seipsum. In the Utrecht calendar St. Pontianus was celebrated on January 14, in the south of France (Albi, Aix, Narbonne) on Nov. 19 or 20 (Grotefend), and Polain dates to 23 Nov. Various dates are thus recorded for this edition. De aetatibus animalium; De aerumnis Herculis; De Herculis laboribus; De Musarum inventis; De cantu Sirenarum; De die natali; De fortuna; De Orpheo; De se ipso; De speculo; Mira Vergilii versus experientia; Mira Vergilii experientia. De quattuor temporibus anni; De ortu solis; De signis caelestibus (all comm. Badius). Badius: liminary letters. Christophorus Landinus: De laude Vergilii. Donatus: Vita Vergilii.
